newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY WHEAT FUTURES SOAR ON FOREIGN DEMAND.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY WHEAT FUTURES SOAR ON FOREIGN DEMAND.

text.p: Hungarian wheat futures soared in brisk trading on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Monday in what traders attributed to the interest of international investors in opening long wheat positions.

Traders said Hungary, which has hundreds of thousands of tonnes of surplus wheat, has no real hope for large-volume exports in the near future, but a price rise wave on international markets boosted Hungarian prices too.
"Multinational investors, large funds may be behind the surge," said LaSalle Rt's Gabor Herczeg.
"In Chicago, and on other forward markets there was a large selling wave in the past two months," he added. "It is not surprising that they want to close these positions somewhere.
The BCE trading concentrated on milling wheat futures, which rose by the limit of 400 forints in almost all maturities.

The settlement price of May milling wheat futures was 25,500 forints per tonne, up by 400. August milling wheat traded in an unusually high turnover of 838 lots and finished at 22,040 forints, up 400 forints.
Maize futures closed easier for all maturities, except October, which remained steady.
